item.title: Github & Hugo workflow
item.description:
There are lots of articles about using Hugo with Github. They are all fairly complex. I spent sometime experimenting with them. in the end I decided, I wanted to simplify.

Requirements

The requirements for me are:

  1. Deploy static site with no cost to me.
  2. I did not need to deploy source. Compiled static site is enough. (e.g. HTML)
  3. Simple, minimal steps from me.

Workflow

This setup will enable me to work in Atom editor on posts, which are saved in the source folder.

On completion of a post. Running the deploy command, will compile the site and move the content to the repo, then commit and push the changes to github.

Setup

Assuming you have hugo and git installed on your machine and setup.

I ended up with the following directory structure. With a deployment bash script.

  ~/TechNotes
      danward79.github.io/
      source/
      deploy.sh
  • The source folder stores the uncompiled hugo site. All edits to posts etc occur here.
  • The repo (danward79.github.io) stores the compiled site and is synced using git commit and git push.
  • deploy.sh is the script that compiles and deploys

Deployment Script - deploy.sh

The deploy script is shown below. It would need editting to suit your setup and situation.

#!/bin/bash

srcPath=~/Documents/Development/Websites/TechNotes/source/
deployPath=~/Documents/Development/Websites/TechNotes/danward79.github.io/
branch='master'

echo 'Deploy changes to Tech Notes'
cd $srcPath

echo 'Building changes'
hugo

echo 'Moving changes to repo'
cp -R $srcPath/public/ $deployPath

echo 'Checkout changes'
cd $deployPath
git checkout $branch
git add -A

echo 'Commit changes'
git commit -m 'Publish Changes'

echo 'Pushing changes'
git push origin master

echo 'Returning to source path'
cd $srcPath

Simple. On completion simply run

bash deploy.sh

item.title: Watchdog on the PI
item.description:
Sometimes, it’s handy to have someone on standby to reset a computer, when it freezes in explicably. There is a tool for this purpose. It’s called a watchdog. On most of the PI’s I have had running I have setup a watchdog for this purpose.

In short a watchdog, will cause either a hard or soft reset to occur, if it is not kicked by the system often enough. The kick is assumed to indicate an operating system.

To install on the Raspberry PI.

From the command line on a standard Rasbian install.

First update Raspbian, note the ‘-y’ flag which suppresses any prompts.

sudo apt-get -y update
sudo apt-get -y upgrade

Expose the watchdog to the operating system. This will create a device at /dev/watchdog

sudo modprobe bcm2708_wdog

Edit module to load at boot. Add the following line.

  • bcm2708_wdog
sudo nano /etc/modules

Install the watchdog service, check it is on and start.

sudo apt-get install watchdog chkconfig
sudo chkconfig watchdog on
sudo /etc/init.d/watchdog start

Open the watchdog config file.

sudo nano /etc/watchdog.conf

In the config uncomment lines with

  • “watchdog-device” and
  • “max-load-1 = 24”

set the following lines to:

  • realtime = yes
  • priority = 1
  • interval = 14

Restart the service.

sudo /etc/init.d/watchdog restart

Test it

To test, lets force the PI to crash. This is known as a Fork-Bomb! Disable swap and then.

sudo swapoff -a
:(){ :|:& };:

You can stop it with: sudo /etc/init.d/watchdog stop OR sudo systemctl stop watchdog.service

You can disable it permanently with: sudo update-rc.d -f watchdog remove OR sudo systemctl disable watchdog.service﻿

References
  1. Watching the dog.

item.title: Mosquitto on the PI
item.description:
MQTT is a publish/subscribe messaging system, Mosquitto is on open source broker.

Install main package

From the command line

sudo apt-get install mosquitto

Install command Line tools

sudo apt-get install mosquitto-clients

Install C Dev Libraries

sudo apt-get install libmosquitto0-dev libmosquittopp0-dev

Test subscription

mosquitto_sub -v -t ‘#’

or alternatively

mosquitto_sub -v -t ‘#’ | xxd

item.title: About
item.description:
If you have landed here, I wonder how you found your way..

How

These pages are hosted as a static site on Github, the static content which forms the pages, is generated with a Go tool called Hugo.

What

On these pages you’ll find some short posts about things/projects/info, which I have taken notes to remember. These pages are for me to recall, how I have done a task and are as such my “Note Book”. I happen to share them, as I hope someone else may find them useful.

Where possible, I do try to give credit by references if they where useful.

Why

Mainly just for my recollection and sometimes, I like to write some stuff.

When

There are no schedules. I make no promises..

C’est la vie.
